2014}}</ref><ref name=Computerworld>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.computerworld.dk/art/112771/dansk-it-direktoer-faar-sin-anden-ph-d-om-algoritmer |title=Dansk it-direktør får sin anden ph.d. - om algoritmer - Computerworld |publisher=Computerworld.dk |date=2012-09-07 |accessdate=2013-06-26}}</ref> Middelfart is the most prolific Danish inventor in the field of database technology.<ref name="Zacco" />  In addition to his patents, Middelfart is a pioneer in the use of the [[OODA]] loop process within business intelligence and data warehousing.<ref name=TEC>{{cite web|url=http://blog.technologyevaluation.com/blog/2011/09/19/thinking-radically-dr-morten-middelfart-cto-of-targit/ |title=Thinking Radically: Dr. Morten Middelfart, CTO of TARGIT » The TEC Blog |publisher=Blog.technologyevaluation.com |date=2011-09-19 |accessdate=2013-06-26}}</ref> The process, as first developed by [[USAF]] Colonel [[John Boyd (military strategist)|John Boyd]], describes the way individuals and

mechanical bellows. The organette was compact and affordable with large selections of music to choose from. Various patents credit [[Henry Bishop Horton]], (1819-1885) co-founder of the Ithaca Calendar Clock Co.<ref>http://www.rollerorgans.com/adverts/1885_Death_of_H_B_Horton.txt</ref><ref>http://ithacacalendarclock.com/1875NEWSPAPERSTORY.html</ref>[[John McTammany]], (1845-1915)<ref>http://www.organettes.com/patents/home?s[]=patents</ref><ref>http://www.amica.org/Live/Publications/Past-Bulletin-Articles/McTammany.PDF</ref>Paul Ehrlich<ref>http://www.organettes.com/patents/home?s[]=patents</ref>and others with the invention of the organette.The organette's popularity declined as the phonograph was introduced and became more affordable to the public.  {{quote|''The most remarkable feature of this invention is the regularity and perfection with which the music is rendered. All of the parts are played and the music is of no mean order.''|''[[Scientific American]]'' 19 November 1879}}

[[File:Organette07.jpg|thumb|<center>Patent 196,529 showing organette structure]] [[File:Ithaca Calendar Clock04.jpg|thumb|<center>Ithaca Calendar Clock]] '''Henry Bishop Horton''' (1 September 1819 [[Winchester, Connecticut]] - 3 December 1885 [[Ithaca, New York]]) was an American inventor, remembered chiefly for his inventions in automatic music players and clock-making. <ref>http://www.rollerorgans.com/adverts/1885_Death_of_H_B_Horton.txt</ref>  About 1823 his family moved to [[Covert, New York]], where he grew up and, when nineteen years old, served for three years as a cabinet maker's apprentice under George Whiton (1801 Stockbridge - 1878 Ithaca). <ref>http://www.hickokfamilygenealogy.com/Hickok/b324.htm#P9520</ref> After this he became involved in the manufacture of melopeans, instruments quite similar to [[Diatonic button accordion|melodeons]]. His taste for music showed itself at an early age and during his lifetime he invented various musical instruments, most celebrated

intelligence]] and [[analytics]]. Middelfart is currently the CIO of [[Genomic Expression]] and founder of Social Quant; both organizations implement the [[data analytics]] techniques Middelfart has developed throughout his career. With seven U.S. [[patent]]s<ref name=Zacco>{{cite web|url=http://morton.dk/inventorUSPTO.pdf|format=PDF|title=Assessment of Dr. Middelfart’s patent activity as inventor|publisher=Morton.dk|accessdate=20 November 2014}}</ref> for his inventions in business intelligence and analytics software, Middelfart holds the most patents of any Danish person working in software.<ref name="Zacco" /> Middelfart holds an [[MBA]] from [[Henley Management College]], a [[PhD]] from [[Rushmore University]], and a PhD from [[Aalborg University]].  Middelfart founded an analytics company, Morton Systems, in 1996, and became CTO of TARGIT following TARGIT’s acquisition of his business in 1997.<ref name=Lab>{{cite
demos.request: What significant invention is Herman Hollerith known for, and what lasting impact did it have on data processing?
demos.reasoning: Herman Hollerith is known for inventing the Hollerith machine, a mechanical tabulator that could quickly and accurately process data. This invention had a significant impact on data processing, as it enabled the rapid and efficient processing of large amounts of data, which was a major breakthrough at the time. The Hollerith machine was used for the 1890 US Census and was later used for other applications, such as business and government data processing.
